abstracts.cdata!:
For the Inner Mongolia Transport and
            Trade Facilitation Project for China, general assessments
            have been conducted on social and economic impacts,
            ecological impacts, noise, and air pollution, among others.
            As the results of those processes, it was concluded that all
            sub-projects might create a few minor, and easily
            recognizable environmental problems, but no significant
            ones. The following are some of the anticipated negative
            environmental impacts, and measures to mitigate them: wastes
            resulting from bridge/culvert construction should not be
            discharged in river channels, to avoid adverse impacts on
            flood discharges capacity, or original river flows;
            destruction of river dykes should be avoided to protect
            flood discharges capacity, particularly in narrower river
            channels; authorities should be notified should new
            archaeological sites be discovered; construction working
            hours should be scheduled to daylight working hours, to
            minimize noise disturbances; construction sites should be
            sprayed, to be maintained clean to prevent air pollution;
            likewise, re-vegetation practices should prevent dusting,
            while topsoil should be restored; tree planting on road
            sides should follow construction; transport vehicles should
            be covered; traffic control shall enforce speed and traffic
            flows; asphalt smoke discharges could be mitigated by
            locating asphalt and lime-mixing plants downwind; the
            cofferdam method should be adopted to effectively prevent
            turbid water quality, and prevent pollution from
            construction waste discharges into rivers. Collection and
            treatment of oil machines should be practiced, thus
            preventing discharges into water bodies. Domestic sewage
            produced from the construction camping sites should be
            centrally treaded, while compost-treated waste may be used
            as a fertilizer for grasslands, however, non-hazardous solid
            waste should be stored in pits. Other measures include
            traffic safety, preventing vehicle overload, hazardous waste
            disposal management.
